questions.question: Which of the following structures does otosclerosis affect?
questions.explanation: Otosclerosis affects the otic capsule, which is the bony structure that surrounds the inner ear.

questions.question: Which layer of the otic capsule is affected in otosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Otosclerosis affects the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. Within the enchondral layer, there are sometimes islands of unossified cartilage rests that later give rise to otosclerosis. The otic capsule is made of 3 layers: 
   • Endosteal: Innermost
   • Enchondral: Middle layer derived from cartilage that ossifies
   • Periosteal: Outermost layer

questions.question: What is the most common site of origin of otosclerosis?
questions.explanation: The most common site of origin of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram, lying in front of the oval window. It is seen in the stapedial type of otosclerosis. Types of otosclerosis: • Stapedial • Cochlear • Histological. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis.

questions.question: What is the type of otosclerotic focus when the disease process involves the entire footplate except for the annular ligament?
questions.explanation:
The otosclerotic focus is biscuit type when the disease process involves the entire footplate except for the annular ligament. The otosclerotic foci in the stapedial type of otosclerosis can be of various types: 
   Anterior focus - involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
   Posterior focus - involving only the fissula post fenestrum
   Circumferential - affects the margin of the footplate only (annular ligament alone)
   Biscuit type affects the entire footplate except for the annular ligament.
   Obliterative - affects the entire footplate and its annular ligament.
   Types of otosclerosis
   A - Anterior focus
   B - Posterior focus
   C - Circumferential
   D - Biscuit type (thick)
   E - Obliterative

questions.question: You are an OBGYN resident and your patient is one of your staff nurses. She is a primigravida who has just been diagnosed with otosclerosis and wants to know its inheritance pattern. Which of the following is the inheritance pattern for otosclerosis?
questions.explanation: Otosclerosis has an autosomal dominant type of inheritance. About 50% of the cases of otosclerosis have a positive family history, while the rest are sporadic. Genetic studies reveal that it is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance and variable expressivity.

questions.question: For research on pharmacological treatment in otosclerosis, a researcher wanted to set the age limit of the study to the most common age group when the hearing loss usually manifests. Which of the following will be a suitable set?
questions.explanation: The most common age group when the hearing loss in otosclerosis usually manifests is 20-30 years of age. It is rare before 10 and after 40 years.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

options.A: Females are affected twice as often as males.
options.B: Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
options.C: HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
options.D: It may be associated with measles.

questions.explanation: HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type. Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males. Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent Eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci, implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.question: Which of the following hearing defects is not seen in otosclerosis?

options.B: Presbyacusis, Progressive conductive hearing loss, Sensorineural hearing loss

questions.explanation: Presbyacusis is not seen in otosclerosis. The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis: • Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly. • Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis. • Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard.

questions.question: A 30-year-old Caucasian woman came with a history of progressive hearing impairment that improves in a noisy environment. Tuning fork tests revealed a conductive hearing loss in both ears. The otoscopic finding is given in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis among the given options?
questions.explanation: The given image is of a normal tympanic membrane. There is bilateral conductive deafness, paracusis willis, and a normal tympanic membrane, which suggest a diagnosis of otosclerosis with matured focus. Paracusis willis - Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard. The tympanic membrane has a normal appearance in most cases. This is indicative of a matured or inactive focus of otosclerotic bone. Option B: A case of CSOM will have a perforated tympanic membrane. Option C: Otosclerosis with an active focus will show the Schwartze sign. Option D: In the case of otitis media with effusion, the tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.

questions.question: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation: The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding, along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness, is seen in active otosclerosis. A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor. Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus. Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.question: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Gelle's is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days. It is based on the fact that in a normal ear, if pressure is increased in the external ear, the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle's test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Stenger's test is done to rule out malingering. Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner. Rinne's is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome. The triad of symptoms is called Van der Hoeve syndrome: 
   1. Osteogenesis imperfecta
   2. Otosclerosis
   3. Blue sclera

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman with a family history of hearing loss in her mother developed a hearing problem during pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral and progressive. Which of the following is the single best investigation to establish a diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the single best investigation to diagnose otosclerosis is impedance audiometry. Option B - In pure tone audiometry (PTA), Carhart's notch with an air-bone gap indicates otosclerosis. Option C - MRI is usually not done. HRCT is the preferred imaging modality for otosclerosis. Option D - Schwabach's test is a tuning fork test that shows conductive hearing loss.

questions.question: Carhart's notch typically dips at which of the following frequencies?

options.A: 4000 Hz in both BC and AC
options.B: 2000 Hz in both BC and AC

questions.explanation: Carhart's notch typically dips at 2000 Hz in bone conduction. Pure tone audiometry in otosclerosis: • Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies. • Bone conduction is normal. • There is a large air-bone gap. • In some cases, there is a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies, but the maximum dip is at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart's notch. Hearing loss in dB, Frequency in Hertz: 125, 250, 500, 1000, 2000. Carhart's notch: 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 100, 1000. Note: Boiler's notch is a similar dip in BC and AC curve but at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced hearing loss.

questions.question: An elderly woman with a history of otosclerosis has now come with worsening deafness. She attained menopause 1 year ago. What would be the most likely report if impedance audiometry was done for her?

options.B: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
options.C: As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
options.D: As graph with increased stapedial reflex

questions.explanation: The above case is suggestive of a long-standing case of otosclerosis and impedance audiometry will show As graph and loss of stapedial reflex as a result of fixation of ossicles. Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear: • Tympanogram - Type As is seen in otosclerosis due to decreased compliance at or near ambient air pressure • Stapedial reflex - Stapedial reflex is lost due to immobile ossicles. Compliance Tympanogram in otosclerosis Normal Type As -200 -1000 +100 +200

questions.question: A patient was diagnosed with otosclerosis and Schwartz's sign was positive on otoscopy. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: Sodium fluoride is used in the medical management of otosclerosis. This is an active case of otosclerosis, evidenced by Schwartz's sign, and in an active case of otosclerosis, medical management is preferred. Surgery is contraindicated if Schwartz's sign is positive. Schwartz's sign - a reddish hue is seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. In an active case of otosclerosis, medical management with sodium fluoride (NaF) is preferred because NaF hastens the maturity of the active focus in otosclerosis. It acts by inhibiting the osteoclasts and decreasing the proteolytic enzymes.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. On examination, the tympanic membrane is normal and the audiogram shows bilateral conductive deafness. Impedance audiometry shows an As type of curve and acoustic reflexes are absent. Which of the following treatment options is not used in patients with the above diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario of bilateral progressive conductive deafness with an As type of tympanogram and absent acoustic reflexes is suggestive of otosclerosis. Gentamicin is not used in the management of otosclerosis. Medical management includes the use of sodium fluoride and bisphosphonates in active cases. Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy, though the latter is preferred due to decreased risk of fistula formation. Hearing aids may be used as an alternative to surgery.

questions.question: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment, which had worsened during her pregnancy. Rinne's test is negative in both ears and Weber's lateralized to the right side. On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis, and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy. Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate and placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice. Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated. NaF is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation. Note: Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence, stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice. In the above case, since Rinne's test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber's test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

questions.question: You are assisting in a stapedotomy procedure for a patient with otosclerosis. After appropriate dissection, where will you place the piston?
questions.explanation: The piston is placed between the incus and oval window. Stapedotomy is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston, which will take over the function of conducting sound. For this reason, the piston replaces the removed stapes superstructure.

questions.question: You are an ENT surgeon and the following are a few patients with otosclerosis. For which of the following patients will you advise stapedotomy?
questions.explanation:
A stapedotomy will be indicated for patients 4 and 5 as bronchial asthma and diabetes without Schwartz's sign are not contraindications for the procedure. Contraindications for Stapedotomy: 
      • Only hearing ear 
      • Positive Schwartz's sign 
      • Otitis externa 
      • Meniere's disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate 
      • Young children 
      • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo. 
      • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

questions.question: An ENT surgeon has referred a patient with otosclerosis posted for stapedotomy to your anesthesia OPD. She has no known co-morbidities. Which of the following techniques will you recommend for the above patient?
questions.explanation: Stapedotomy is preferred to be done under local anesthesia because: immediate on-table improvement of hearing can be assessed, damage to the inner ear can be assessed by the patient's symptoms of vertigo/nystagmus, and damage to the facial nerve can be checked.

questions.question: In a patient with otosclerosis who underwent stapedotomy, which of the following complications is least likely?
questions.explanation: Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy. Complications of stapedotomy include: Sensorineural hearing loss, injury to the facial nerve, floating/submerged footplate, endolymph gush due to damage to the inner ear, dislodgement of piston, post-operative vertigo, and dead ear.

questions.question: In Lempert's fenestration, an alternative window is created in which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: Lempert's fenestration, an alternative window is created in the lateral semicircular canal to function for the obliterated oval window. Lempert's fenestration operation for otosclerosis is outdated now. It has the disadvantage of a postoperative mastoid cavity and an inherent hearing loss of 25 dB, which cannot be corrected.
